title: 106_hr1444
content:
The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary of the Interior. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects under the Program include developing fish screens and passage devices to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Secretary shall prioritize projects with a total cost under $5,000,000, based on inventories by States on project needs and priorities, as agreed upon by non-Federal interests, relevant Federal and tribal agencies, and affected States. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Federal projects on U.S. land are nonreimbursable.

SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Projects are evaluated based on benefits to native fish species, water diversion size, funding availability, cost effectiveness, and additional system benefits.

SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. Projects must meet Secretary and State requirements, and have approval from all relevant entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and use available data to determine project eligibility. The non-Federal share of costs for projects under the Program on non-Federal land is 35%. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land, easements, and other resources. The value of these contributions will be credited towards the non-Federal share. Non-Federal participants are responsible for operating and maintaining the project, while the Federal Government has its own responsibilities. The Federal Government is responsible for costs of projects on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from other sources for the same purpose.

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be finished with remaining funds, and recommended Program changes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations: 25% funds per state, 6% for administrative expenses. Waiver possible for unused funds.
